captions.text:
Welcome to the League of Legends Champion Spotlight,
featuring Azir, the Emperor of the Sands.

Azir is the ascended leader of the ancient empire
of Shurima. Now that he’s back, he won’t rest until

he’s returned his kingdom, his people - and himself
- to glory.

Azir’s a mid-lane mage who summons and controls
an army of sand soldiers. The soldiers are an extension

of their Emperor’s will, literally attacking for
Azir and controlling areas of the map with their
lethal spears.

Azir has two passives. The first, Will of the Emperor
grants Azir bonus attack speed based on his cooldown

reduction. This goes for cooldown reduction granted
by items as well as runes, masteries and buffs.
Azir’s second passive, actually an active, is Disc

of the Sun, which builds a Shuriman Sun Disc at
the base of a destroyed turret.
The Sun Disc targets enemies just like other turrets and lasts for a
minute before returning to sand, but it can be
brought down faster by enemies, awarding gold when destroyed.
The Sun Disc’s kills and assists rack
up gold and experience for Azir.

If Azir strays too far from the Sun Disc, it loses
tons of armor and will fall,
even to minions, quite quickly.

Note that Azir can build the Sun Disc
on any destroyed turret,
except for enemy inhibitor and nexus turrets.

Azir’s a conqueror, and that means he takes your
turrets...literally. Disc of the Sun is great for
protecting your team as you push into enemy territory.
Let’s start with Azir’s W, Arise! because it’s

the only ability he can actually learn at Level
1 and crucial to the rest of his kit.

Arise! summons the untargettable
memory of a Shuriman soldier
that grants vision and waits for commands.
If a Sand Soldier’s in range to attack an enemy,

Azir’s auto attack will order
his soldiers to attack instead.

There’s no need to get your hands dirty.
You’re the emperor.

Arise! operates on an ammo system that maxes out
at two charges. While there’s no hard limit on

the number of soldiers Azir can have in play, they
do time out after a few seconds. If more than one

soldier is attacking the same target, the damage
of extra soldiers is significantly reduced.

Sand Soldiers benefit from Azir’s attack speed bonuses
and their damage scales with his ability power.
Note that soldier’s attacks pierce through their

initial target, extending their attack range beyond
the circle you see.

Soldier’s attacks make up Azir’s primary source
of magic damage and apply on-spell-hit effects.

Meaning they’ll pop spell shields, apply Rylai’s,
Liandry’s and spellvamp,
but not Red buff, Nashor’s Tooth, or Lich Bane.

Using soldiers extends Azir’s basic attack range,
but only up to a point. When he moves a certain

distance away, the soldier becomes inactive and
if Azir moves much farther, it disappears altogether.
Sand soldiers are afraid of enemy turrets.

They refuse to attack them and disappear much faster
when one’s around. Buncha wimps. However, Azir
can cast Arise directly on an enemy turret to immediately deal damage
instead of spawning a cowardly soldier.
In lane, Soldier attacks are Azir’s primary tool

for farming up large groups of minions and harassing
lane opponents.

Now that Azir’s remembered some soldiers, it’s
time to learn about his Q, Conquering Sands.

When Azir casts Conquering Sands, every soldier
charges to the target location, no matter how far
they are from the emperor.

When charging, soldiers slow and damage each target
they pass through.
If multiple soldiers hit the same target, the slow stacks but each strike after the first deals reduced damage.

Use Conquering Sands to slow your opponent, allowing
your soldiers to squeeze in an extra stab or two.

Azir’s E, Shifting Sands is how the emperor gets
in or out of trouble.

On cast, Azir dashes to a target soldier,
damaging and knocking up enemies along the way.

If Azir collides with an enemy champion
he also gains a temporary shield and stops in place.
Remember that Azir can dash to any active soldier,

even if they’re on the other side of a wall. Additionally,
Azir can cast spells mid-dash to reposition his
soldiers without affecting his destination.

Shifting Sands is especially useful for escaping
ganks and dodging dangerous enemy spells.

Azir’s ultimate, Emperor’s Divide, summons a wall
of shield-bearing Soldiers that charge in a target
direction, damaging and knocking back enemies.
These soldiers don’t take orders, but they do stick

around, blocking enemy movement while allowing
allies to pass through, and providing a nifty movement
speed boost in the process.

Even if an enemy tries to dash through or jump
over the wall, the soldiers still knock ‘em back.
Get bopped!

Some exceptions apply. Flash, and flash-like abilities
allow you to pass the wall unbopped.

And the unstoppable force of some abilities can
still pass through Emperor’s Divide.

Azir and his allies can pass through the wall multiple
times to refresh the speed boost.

Use Emperor’s Divide in teamfights to split the
enemy team and protect your backline.

Mastering Azir means mastering his sand soldiers.
These essential tactics will help your army win
control of the Rift.

In lane, CS and zone out your enemy by keeping
a soldier behind the back line of caster minions.

When your opponent comes in to last hit, attack
them then slow them with Q to get a few more hits in.

It’s definitely Darude-st way to deny minion
gold from your opponent.

In duels, keep your distance, placing sand soldiers
ahead of Azir and leading your opponent through them.

Move and attack. Move and attack. Your soldiers will
do the dirty work while you kite around for safety.

If your opponent gets in close, use Q to
slow 'em down and get the troops together for DPS.

This will either turn the fight around, or ensure you
don’t go down without dealing some serious damage.

In situations where you’re feeling gutsy or maybe
just have backup from your allies, create a sand
soldier and send it behind your enemy with Q. Approaching at a slight angle, E to your soldier and ult

back in the direction you came from, splitting up the
enemy team or picking off an out of position enemy

champion. Keep in mind this is a very risky play,
so choose your moment carefully.

Even when you have the upper hand, keep in mind
that Shifting Sands is your only way in or out

of a fight, so take care not to go on offense without
checking your surroundings first. Here, Azir dashes in

without vision, wasting his escape tool just as
the enemy jungler rolls into the lane. #punsofdamage.
Azir’s at home in newly conquered territory because

of the Sun Disc’s tower-like strength. Here, Twitch
doesn’t respect its TrueSight and gets rekt, while

his allies make the smarter play, making sure not
to pull aggro by attacking Azir and patiently knocking
down the Disc before advancing on the Emperor.
Azir has to stay close to his soldiers to keep
pumping out damage. Here, Azir misses his Q>E combo on a fishing trip, but keeps chasing, using Conquering
Sands to apply a slow and deal damage as Nami flees.
When her allies come in to help, he slows them

with his Q, but his escape is still on cooldown,
forcing him to burn Emperor’s Divide defensively.

Shifting Sands comes off cooldown in the nick of
time to save Azir from Ahri’s Flash-Charm combo,

allowing Azir to W>E escape and secure his original
target. Afterward, Azir kites and slows Darius

with Conquering Sands, letting his team swoop in
for the last kill.

Azir is capable of changing the landscape of a
fight. With Emperor’s Divide and a deft Q>E Azir

blocks off Sejuani while escaping, neutralizing
her chase. Now joining his team, Azir does three

things with Disc of the Sun: he protects his flank,
traps Ziggs between turrets and deals some extra

damage. Azir dodges what skillshots he can, and
prioritizes kiting over damage, staying alive and
allowing his team to secure the kill.

Let’s put it all together in this teamfight. First,
Azir needs to land soldier basic attacks to be

useful. Here, he puts down soldiers and takes Annie
out of the fight quickly.

Next, Azir identifies that he can push
the enemy squishies into his own allies.
Shifting Sands and Flash get Azir behind the enemy team for
the Emperor’s Divide Insec into his waiting allies.
Azir understands he can beat Skarner
with the knockup and shield from Shifting Sands.
After winning the duel and Skarner retreating,

Azir closes distance with a slick W, E, Q combo
allowing him to basic attack and skewer the scorpion.
Thanks for tuning into the Azir Champion Spotlight.

Please subscribe to the Riot Games YouTube channel
and leave us your comments just below the video.

comments.author: Mixael Lotarov

comments.text:
if you ever played azir and are wondering why he doesn't seem very good, 
this spotlight doesn't talk about an extremely important mechanic mastered 
by all pro azir players:

You can use conquering sands (Q) while dashing with shifting sands (E). 
This changes everything about azir, absolutely everything. His escape 
range, his engage potential, his combo speed, his burst...

When I first bought Azir i didn't know that, but after I realized u could 
do that Azir went from fucking sloppy to play to fucking awesome.﻿
